IRS990.MissionDescription: The mission of The Institute of Internal Auditors is to provide dynamic leadership for the global profession of internal auditing.
IRS990.Description: Training and education for internal auditors.

Activity2.Description: Publications which inform internal auditors and I.I.A. members of current professional issues, standards and practices.

Activity3.Description: Offering examinations on professional issues and certifying those who demonstrate acceptable performance.

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Identifier: Procedure for Monitoring Grants in the U.S.:
Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2: The Organization oversees the activities of the grant recipient through overlapping management and leadership.

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: The Organization paid for first-class travel for the domestic portion of an international trip taken by the President when the international business class airfare proved to be less expensive than coach. The Organization also paid for first-class travel for a portion of a trip taken by an officer in order for the officer to arrive at his destination by a specific time. The Organization paid the travel costs of the spouses of two officers to attend the Organization's international conference. The spouses act as a welcoming committee to the delegates and their spouses. As such, the spouses perform significant duties for the Organization at the conference and their travel is for a bona fide business purpose of the Organization. Reimbursement of travel for applicable spouses of officers to attend the annual international conference is in accordance with the Organization's Board Policy Manual.

The President, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Information Officer of the Organization participate in a nonqualified Section 457(f) deferred compensation plan. Contributions totaling $44,000 were deposited into the plan during the year ended December 31, 2010 on behalf of these individuals.

The Organization has adopted an executive compensation setting policy applicable to all disqualified persons, including the Organization's President, officers and key employees. Under the policy, an independent committee of the Board of Directors annually reviews and approves the compensation levels of all individuals subject to the policy. The deliberations and decisions of the committee are contemporaneously substantiated. The committee utilizes comparability data in its deliberations; updated comparability data is generally obtained annually.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 6
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Organization is a membership organization and therefore has members.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 7a
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The classes of the membership of the Organization include: Member, Educational Member, Student Member, Retired Member. All classes of membership can vote at membership meetings. Those members who are Certified Internal Auditors may also serve as officers or directors of the Organization.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 7b
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: If an amendment of the Bylaws of the Organization is approved by a majority of the Board of Directors, it must then be approved by a majority of the voting members before it is declared effective.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Organization's top management official and top financial official each review the Form 990 prior to its filing with the IRS. The Form 990 is also reviewed by the Global Finance Committee, the North American Board, and the entire Executive Committee of the Organization prior to its filing with the IRS. Finally, a copy of the Form 990 is provided to all members of the Board of Directors prior to its filing with the IRS.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Organization's conflict of interest policy is distributed to each member of the Organization's governing body, its officers, and its key employees on an annual basis. Each such individual provides an annual disclosure statement indicating that they have received, read, understood and agreed to comply with the policy, and certifying that: (1) they have no relationships or interests that present a conflict of interest, (2) they have one or more conflicts of interest that have been fully disclosed as required by the policy and have been properly administered in conformity with the policy, or (3) they have previously undisclosed conflicts of interest and disclosing the details of such conflicts. Any disclosure statements with previously undisclosed conflicts of interest are forwarded to appropriate Organization officials to take appropriate actions as required by the policy.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Organization has adopted an executive compensation setting policy applicable to all disqualified persons, including the Organization's CEO, officers and key employees. Under the policy, an independent committee of the Board of Directors annually reviews and approves the compensation levels of all individuals subject to the policy. The deliberations and decisions of the committee are contemporaneously substantiated. The committee utilizes comparability data in its deliberations; updated comparability data is generally obtained annually.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Institute of Internal Auditors, Inc. provides, upon request, copies of its Articles of Incorporation, bylaws, conflict of interest policy, and financial statements. The Organization's financial statements can also be accessed via its website.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VII, Section A, Line 1a, Column B:
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Guenther Meggeneder, Philip D. Tarling, Michael J.A. Parkinson and Dennis K. Beran each devoted an average of 2 hours per week to related organizations. Richard F. Chambers, David N. Polansky, Paul J. Sobel and Patricia E. Scipio each devoted an average of 4 hours per week to related organizations.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VII, Section A, Line 1a:
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: During the year ended December 31, 2010, the Organization paid $70,000 to Basil Woller & Associates, LLC for consulting services. Basil Woller & Associates, LLC is 100% owned by director Basil R. Woller.
